author: Maarten Mittner
title: Bonds weaker as Brazil is cut to ‘junk’ status | Markets
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Rand firmer amid volatile trade ahead of US Fed rate decision SOUTH African bonds were weaker in the late afternoon on Thursday after ratings agency Standard & Poor’s (S&P) cut Brazil’s credit rating to "junk" status.
That means the country has lost its investment-grade rating. Higher interest rates are now payable on Brazil’s debt, worsening its already high indebtedness. Brazil is the second Brics country after Russia to be downgraded to "junk" status.
At 3.32pm, the benchmark R186 was bid at 8.525% and offered at 8.510% from Wednesday’s close of 8.445%.
The middle-dated R207 was bid at 8.045% and offered at 8.035% from a previous close of 7.995%.
The rand was at R13.7895 to the dollar from R13.7978 at Wednesday’s close.
Nedbank Capital said in a note the S&P’s downgrading of Brazil on growth concerns had had an effect on the local market.
"Markets should remain volatile until the Federal open market committee meeting next week Thursday."
The chances of a hike in September are at 28% and at 57.5% for December.
"This should see the R186 trade in a range over the next couple of sessions," Nedbank said.
